p: Mosquito traps have served for decades as effective surveillance tools but have only recently been considered under VCAG as a control strategy ( Fig 1). For a trap to be an efficient tool for vector elimination, it must be highly sensitive and specific for a target species. The most effective traps rely on a combination of attractant cues such as light, heat, moisture, carbon dioxide, and synthetic chemicals for host attraction [ 34]. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) miniature light trap was introduced in 1962 [ 35], but major advances have been made with newer traps that have incorporated innovations such as carbon dioxide plumes and counter flow geometry [ 36]. Another trap recently developed is the Mosquito Magnet Pro (MMPro), which is commercially available and uses propane, making it affordable and easily deployable for the general public.
